title: Annoying =/= OverPowered. I cannot stress this enough
body:
Please, stop confusing these two terms. Just because a champion is not fun to play against, annoying, it does not mean that particular champion is some broken, OP character who should be gutted and nerfed into oblivion until it no longer sees play.

Also, too often I see mains who have clearly mastered a champion, who know its ins and outs trying to explain its weaknesses and how to capitalize on them and instead of paying attention and taking into account the pieces of advice that have been given to them, some players would much rather just do nothing about improving their own gameplay and just ask for nerfs, since that is the easy way out.

All I'm asking you to do is take the time to look into the champion you most despise, play a few games with it and maybe watch someone play it and get to know their strengths and weaknesses. I promise you, this will make your gameplay much more enjoyable and who knows, maybe it will open up some opportunities. 
Take me for example, I used to hate Yasuo's guts so much that I would just complain about him over and over again for being annoying and OP until I decided I should try him out and see what he's about and what his power is and how I can work around it. Well, as it turned out he's quite a lot of fun to play and he's only recently become a tad bit stronger, but a few months ago I used to find him OP then once I tried him out it was clear to me that he was not the source of my problems, but me being close minded.

* **EDIT**: _I gave Yasuo just as an example as to why you shouldn't judge a book by its covers. Don't take it so seriously. The point of the post has nothing to do with Yasuo alone, but rather with every champion that might be getting hate or what not_
* **EDIT2**: _Typos_

I'm not on the hate train for Yasuo, I think Jax is far worse atm. That said...

-He has two POWERFUL passives that are very meaningful at all points of the game. J4 has seen a LOT of hate in League, maybe not right now but that was a really poor example.
-Yasuo's Q has nearly 0 CD, as does his E depending on usage.
-Yasuo's crit is slightly less than others but his overall DPS is FAR higher, especially early on when they can't crit as often making even his normal hits far more powerful before considering his DPS combo. He can also put out 3 autos-6 autos in the time another champ can auto 1-2x nullfying any argument of "reduced damage" because of nonsense like auto->Q/E->canceling. His ult does a crazy amount of damage and gives MASSIVE armor penetration on all targets for a rather long period of time meaning no one really beats his damage. In the end... Tons of damage!
-It has crap damage before considering that it will crit every time almost, it can reset his auto attacks, it is extremely extremely spammable, and can reach 3 charges in about 6 or less seconds at max reduction, also procs Shiv which will hurt even more than usual because it is almost guaranteed to crit every activation. Yasuo has a Wind Wall to negate obscene amounts of damage, he has a shield, he does extremely high damage and can further survive by healing off his crazy damage or outright insta-kill a target, and he has his dash for substantial mobility to outplay with. He can grab 2-3 offensive items and go full tank and still obliterate, and he can ignore armor penetration items unlike other ADCs due to his crazy ult.
-His mobility can be used over walls to escape to jungle camps, it can be used to dash around in lane forcing minion harass or just to kite an enemy or create significant distance. While his mobility is situational it definitely has uses for keeping him alive rather than just sheer offensively charging the target. Zed is an unfair comparison. No one really has Zed's safety.

It actually makes a lot of sense. And seems to be quite a fair statement. I don't see why you would attack that point in their argument seeing how logical it is.

If player X (consistently) loses against champion Y, but player Z (consistently) wins against champion Y despite both having access to the same given tools, then it's quite clear that player X does not know how to play against a champion Y, and that player Z does, and the issue is that player X needs to figure out how to play like player Z in order to be successful.

For example, Blitzcrank, most high level players in understand that the best way to counter blitz in lane, is to put a minion (an allied one) between you and the robot, and if he walks into the bush, to ward that bush (and then put a friendly minion between you and the robot). Late game, the solution is quite similar, make sure someone else (like your team's amumu) is between you and blitz. But there's a lot of low level players out there who don't know that and that's one of the reasons why they struggle against him. And a lot of these players who fail complain on the boards about him. The issue is that they don't know how to play against the champion rather than the champion being broken or OP. It's punishing a mistake that the player should learn to not make.

As another example, Katarina, most high level players understand that much of Katarina's damage comes from her ultimate which is channelled and requires her to stand still, but can be disrupted through the use of hard cc. her natural item build encourages her to forego defenses meaning that if she dives into a large group of champions and is immediately stunned, then she will die before the stun ends. And again, in low levels of play, players don't hold onto their cc abilities and instead rely on firing every button at the same time at the start of a teamfight resulting in katarina punishing her enemies for making the mistake of not prioritizing her as a dangerous threat and preparing accordingly (mentally or physically).

There is a huge flaw in your reasoning and there are several points that need to be addressed. First of all, overpowered does not mean unbeatable, it means over-tuned in one area or another or even several aspects. If Player X can consistently win against Yasuo however Player Y cannot for example, simply means Player X average champion pool are made up of counters for Yasuo while Player Y is not. You can beat yasuo with Zed or constant ganks but it does not mean that he is balanced.

And that's the main reason why people have a problem with Yasuo.  When facing most champions, you can set up things yourself with the tools provided by your own kit.  When facing a Yasuo, you need wait for HIM to set things up, and he's not going to do that unless he thinks he can win.  You need to work around other champions too, don't get me wrong, but for Yasuo it's a whole new level.  

You need to wait for him to make a mistake, but with his shield and wall and mobility, he can make a few and still be okay overall.  However, if you make even a small mistake against Yasuo, in most cases, you're not going to get out alive.

I don't play many immobile mages, sorry. But the ones I do ... Lissandra, Syndra, Morgana, and Zyra all have a similar trait. They can all heavily punish his mistakes (excluding Syndra, to a degree). One of the things I hate about Yasuo is that he completely dictates the lane. Your play style revolves around how good or bad he is. But the number one thing you can carry over to all matchups is trading ability. **Learn to harass with Auto Attacks and you have a significantly higher chance of winning lane. **

The first thing you do against Yasuo is talk to your jungler. As soon as the game starts you tell him, "Hey, Yasuo is going to push the lane, if you gank mid it'll be an easy kill." If your jungler isn't a complete potato he will be ready to gank your lane 24/7. Yasuo likes to push the lane, that's what he does, he pushes and pushes and pushes to apply pressure. But any half-competent jungler will punish him hard for doing so. If I jungle against Yasuo, I camp him. As soon as he is locked in my jungler senses go: first gank already determined. Remember this, toxic players are attracted to toxic champions. I've camped Yasuo's so hard that they tilted off the face of the Earth. They've raged and called me everything under the sun. I love it. 

Which brings us to our next "ability" ... tilting. As bad as it sounds, trying to tilt someone is a legitimate strategy and it actually works. Yasuo is broken, and as such, anyone that plays him will go into a match thinking they will stomp hard and is Faker-incarnate. You need to play off this ego. I wont go into details but all chat is a weapon. 

If you are going to play an immobile mage against Yasuo, they need hard CC and peel: 

Yasuo gets close to Liss? Root him, wreck him. 
Yasuo gets close to Lux? Root him, wreck him.
Yasuo gets close to Morgana? Root him, wreck him.
Yasuo gets close to Zyra? Root him, wreck him. 
Yasuo gets close to Syndra? Knockback-stun him, wreck him.

See the common theme here? If he gets within melee range of any of them they can punish him heavily without taking much damage. 

Finally, **conserve your mana and learn to farm under the turret!** This is the most important thing. Lets assume you are going against a REALLY aggressive Yasuo and he is pushing you under the turret and chucking tornado's at you. Most people will panic and throw out every spell they have to kill the minions. DO NOT DO THIS! If Yasuo is going to push the lane, let him. Conserve your mana and relax. He is screwing himself by doing this. All you have to do is let the tower do the work and wait for your jungler to come. He cant kill you under the tower, so he cant snowball. All he's doing is making himself an easy gank target. If you blow all your mana trying to keep the lane even, you lose. Game over. Once you have no mana, it becomes hard to cs and you can no longer harass, even if your jungler does come you cant help him with no mana. 

If he is determined to push you under the turret, and you are panicking, let the current minion wave die. Dont even try to kill any of the minions. Walk under your turret. Take a deep breath, and wait for the lane to reset. Then remember this:

Melee minions = 2 turret shots + 1 Auto Attack
Caster minions = 1 Auto Attack + 1 turret shot + 1 Auto Attack

Missing one wave is better than staying in panic mode, burning through all your mana, and losing lane. Just relax. I would go into more detail but this post is already an essay so I wont turn it into a novel. Good luck.

I feel her shield needs something changed, Everything else is doable but that shield is just out of place and too strong on a champion that is supposed to ONLY do damage, why does she need an Insane shield on top of the mobility that it gives her, no matter how short it is, mobility is strong.

I think the problem with the shield is the scaling of the shield itself, from what I've seen. Not the fact that she gets access to a scaling shield, but just that it scales at a 1:1 ratio. If it was 1:0.5 or something more similar, it'd be much easier to deal with her snowballing, and it'd be easier for a champion to pop her shield and make damage stick. Just remember that the main drawback to nerfing her shield is basically forcing her into being a pure 1v1 champion, because in a teamfight setting a lot of AoE can go out and pop her shield on accident. Also, if she's CC'd by anything that prevents movement, she loses access to half of her kit outright (including her main defensive tool, as a largely squishy melee champion, and her main offensive gap-closer), unlike a lot of champions, which makes her more vulnerable to CC than you'd initially think. Now, I know most champions are vulnerable to CC, but several of them hurt Riven even more. 

There's also the animation cancelling thing, which I don't have enough insight on high-level Riven play to properly weigh-in on, I'll admit. So if you have more insight to that (and thus, the speed she unlocks to pop squishies at her vaunted speed), please inform me because I'll listen to someone willing to talk rationally about Riven like you have so far.

Why do people keep making these types of characters?
